> [{quoted}](name=OniZetsu666,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=mEzM6IuY,comment-id=000100000000000000000001,timestamp=2017-12-31T02:46:58.435+0000)Not gonna lie it feels like riot is really limiting everyone speech.

I'll be honest -- speaking purely for myself, if someone feels like they're being unduly restricted by being asked not to call other players bad, or insult them, or use hate speech, or blame people nonstop for mistakes, I'm happy to have them out of the *League* community. Avoiding that stuff really isn't hard, and shouldn't be a burden on anyone. There are plenty of ways to express your emotions and opinions without putting down other people.

>Notice how a ton of your players are afraid to use the chat? 

This really isn't true. Sure, some percentage of punished players avoid the chat, but the people we see on this forum are a small subset of a small subset. There are only a few thousand board users compared to *millions and millions* of *League* players, and only a small portion of those few thousand post here, and only a small portion of THOSE are afraid to use chat.

>Its because of things like this. I know that its not your fault mods but you are representing the company... you can't tell me that a lot of these chats bans are...well...odd.

I see very few bans I consider completely unjustified, actually. I see some that are relatively minor in the big scheme of things, but most of those are the result of repeated escalations by someone who is clearly not putting the time into properly changing their behavior. Those that ARE odd or borderline I encourage to submit a ticket to Player Support, who are usually really good at reversing the rare bans that are legitimate errors.

> I get it you want your players to feel safe but when we don't feel safe by your system somethings wrong..when people are afraid of saying the littlest of things because they are afraid of getting into trouble something is not right.

The people who are afraid of using chat usually either A: don't understand how the system works, or B: fall into the category of those who feel attacked and restrained by an inability to insult, harass, or blame others on a regular basis. Exceptions exist, but I've found them to be rare once the system is properly explained.

> I'll be honest -- speaking purely for myself, if someone feels like they're being unduly restricted by being asked not to call other players bad, or insult them, or use hate speech, or blame people nonstop for mistakes, I'm happy to have them out of the *League* community. Avoiding that stuff really isn't hard, and shouldn't be a burden on anyone. There are plenty of ways to express your emotions and opinions without putting down other people.

Glad you are only a mod and not actually an employee of this company, because that is an extremely biased statement. Not saying I agree or disagree, but it's not your right to tell other people how to speak and behave.

> [{quoted}](name=Crimson Elite ,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=mEzM6IuY,comment-id=00010000000000000000000100010000,timestamp=2017-12-31T03:22:33.138+0000)
>
> - Basically, what I read was: **If I don't like you, you or your attitude you shouldn't be allowed to play this game with me. **

Nah. It's more like "if it's a burden to you to be asked not harass or insult others and you're not willing to adapt your behavior, I personally feel you don't belong in the type of community Riot is trying to build." I'm totally cool with people and attitudes I don't approve of -- I just feel that insulting and harassing other players is a step too far, especially since everyone playing agreed to abide by the Summoner's Code, which asks you not to do that.

> Glad you are only a mod and not actually an employee of this company, because that is an extremely biased statement. Not saying I agree or disagree, but it's not your right to tell other people how to speak and behave.

It's not, nor is it how I moderate. Hence the "speaking purely for myself." I can hold personal opinions on what should or shouldn't be okay and still stick heavily to set rules, even when and where I disagree with them. I'm positive not every Rioter agrees with the official Riot policies 100% as well, and that's fine -- as individuals we're all allowed to have our own opinions. :)

The simple fact, however, is that, as a private organization, Riot is allowed to set rules for behavior, much like how if you start screaming at your local coffee shop they can (and likely will) ask you to leave and not come back. Private organizations have always been allowed to restrict acceptable behaviors on their property, be it real-world or digital property.

Sorry about the dig at you not being an employee. I went too far there, my bad. :(

I think you are missing the point of the op. The burden is not being able to banter or insult someone, the burden is a player having to limit what they say out of fear. With this new system, I could say a relatively harmless thing, but if someone takes it the wrong way I could face consequences. Reports are being given too much weight right now.

This isn't really the case, in my experience -- pretty much *every* false ban I've ever seen on the boards was resolved with a simple ticket to Player Support. What's far more common are people not understanding that repeated blame, statements of how toxic someone is being, and so forth are in fact lesser forms of harassment. I really don't typically see harmless things causing people punishments.

I feel like dealing with riot support is not worth the effort it takes to correct a false ban. There need to be a better way to improve the system's accuracy.

 I don't think its a matter of whether people are being toxic or not, people will always be toxic in a competitive environment. It should be easier to correct someone or tell them to stop bugging you without the system punishing you. If someone is harassing me, its much quicker to type "stfu" than to say "pls stop harassing me and play". Same with when someone makes mistakes. Its easier to type " that was bad, stay grouped, dont frontline" than to explain in full detail how someone's play was bad and what they should be doing to win. Both are harmless given the context, but still could contribute to a ban.

> [{quoted}](name=Crimson Elite ,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=mEzM6IuY,comment-id=000100000000000000000001000100000000000000000000,timestamp=2017-12-31T04:23:49.911+0000)I don't think its a matter of whether people are being toxic or not, people will always be toxic in a competitive environment.

Some people will always be toxic in ANY environment. That's a poor excuse to say "well, we just have to live with people being assholes everywhere."

>If someone is harassing me, its much quicker to type "stfu" than to say "pls stop harassing me and play". 

"STOP" is just as short as "STFU," and doesn't have the same negative connotations. "Knock it off" is also pretty short to type. Take the extra half second -- if you're typing in a time when you don't have 1.5 seconds, you should likely be playing instead. :P

>Same with when someone makes mistakes. Its easier to type " that was bad, stay grouped, dont frontline" than to explain in full detail how someone's play was bad and what they should be doing to win. Both are harmless given the context, but still could contribute to a ban.

"That was bad, stay groups, don't frontline" is almost certainly 100% fine, unless you keep telling your team everything is bad over and over and NEVER offer productive input or positive feedback. "YOU are bad, stay grouped, don't frontline" is a problem.

> [{quoted}](name=Crimson Elite ,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=mEzM6IuY,comment-id=00010000000000000000000100010000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2017-12-31T04:46:54.036+0000)But that's the way the real world works. 

And yet movie theaters, bars, bookstores, etc. still frequently ask people to leave for treating their fellow patrons with disrespect. There's no reason a game *can't* request certain behaviors. Just because people are sometimes jerks doesn't mean we have to accommodate that behavior.

> I wouldn't say its an excuse, but often you have to sacrifice your own ego in order to compete at higher levels of play. The better a player is, the more critical he will be of his team-mates in most cases.

And that's fine. No one is asking them not to be critical -- they're asking them to BE RESPECTFUL IN THEIR CRITICISM. That shouldn't be an unreasonable bar to set.

It's also easier to work off of your account. So getting a ban from it means that it's consistent AND the player isn't showing improvement.

This is my experience as well. When you set out to be a friendly, encouraging, supporting teammate who engages people and encourages the same in return, you tend to run into a lot more friendly, chill players than you do assholes. Toxicity breeds toxicity, and the opposite is generally true as well. :)

>My main fear is the system being abused and for heavy censorship. That is my main concern for people.

I wouldn't worry unduly. It's only purpose is to remove those players who insult and harass others, or spread negativity at an alarming rate. There's also some leeway built in that catches those players who have a bit of a bad day here or there, so long as those bad days don't include zero-tolerance language. To actually earn a permanent ban you either need to be consistently problematic over a long period of time (and through multiple warnings) OR be truly and egregiously toxic. Accounts can recover their standing through good behavior, so escalating all the way to a permanent ban takes effort -- or, rather, takes NO inclination to admit you might be wrong and show reform. Most players have NOTHING to worry about. :)

And hey! Welcome to *League.* Glad to have you. :)
